mtp-project.title: S 272nd/277th St Corridor Capacity & Non Motorized Trail Improvements
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes. The project is included in the City of Auburn 2015-2020 TIP as project #6. It is also included in the City of Auburn Comprehensive Transportation Plan.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes. King County and the City of Kent are in concurrence with the revised project.
mtp-project.funds-description: Federal grant funding was secured for design and ROW through PSRC, and construction funding was secured with a TIB grant. Local funds are programmed, and Robertson Property Group has executed an agreement to participate in the project financially and with the dedication of ROW.

mtp-project.title: Seattle South End Transit Pathways
mtp-project.description: Establish transit pathways between South Portal of SR 99 and 3rd Ave transit spine, funding only shows cost for Columbia Street from 1st Avenue to 3rd Avenue.

mtp-project.title: Highline Community College Intermodal Transit Facility and Parking Garage
mtp-project.description: Construct a Transit Center with bus layover to facilitate a potential Bus Rapid Transit route on SR 99 in south King County. In addition, the project will construct a parking garage with up to 500 stalls that will provide commuter parking, vanpool and carpool stalls as well as joint use parking for Highline Community College students and staff. This project has been deferred so that it can be coordinated with the ongoing environmental/preliminary planning process for Sound Transi's Federal Way Link extensio project, which will include a station in the vicinity of Highline College.
mtp-project.planning-process: x
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: x
mtp-project.funds-description: x

mtp-project.title: Madison Street Corridor BRT
mtp-project.description: Madison Street BRT project led by SDOT, currently has no financial partnership with King County Metro Transit

mtp-project.title: Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 Park & Ride/Bus Turnaround Facility (Spanaway)
mtp-project.description: 350 new parking stalls
mtp-project.planning-process: Pierce County – Title 19A – Comprehensive Plan (Adopted 1994; Transit Element not Updated in 2013 along with the rest of the Plan) • Objective 1. TRANSIT: Recognize that transit and ridesharing are important elements of the transportation system. • H. Transit Access: Pierce County encourages transit access by: 1. Improving bicycle and pedestrian access to proposed transit centers, rail stations, and bus stops. 2. Working with Pierce Transit and the development industry to integrate transit facilities (e.g., transfer centers, bus pullouts, bus shelters, transit information centers) and safe and convenient pedestrian and bicycle connections into residential, retail, manufacturing, commercial, and other types of activity centers.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, not yet as funding for the project has not been secured. Nor has an initial site assessment been conducted, etc.
mtp-project.location: Please delete Endpoint A below (i.e., leave blank)
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

mtp-project.title: Redmond Central Connector
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes, the project remains in Redmond's Comprehensive Plan. The project is envisioned in the Comprehensive Plan, has a master plan, and is included in Redmond's Transportation Master Plan. Policy: PR-51 Coordinate with King County, Sound Transit and other regional partners on the planning and development of the Redmond Central Connector, along the former Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad corridor, as a regional trail with opportunities for community gathering, art, culture and historic interpretation, as well as for light rail transit, options for other transportation connections and utility placement.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes. Details continue to be worked out the eastside rail corridor efforts to determine the best route to link the terminus of the project at 124th Street to the Eastside Rail Corridor mainline trail.
mtp-project.funds-description: Phase I has been completed and Phase II will begin construction soon. Phase III to 124th Street is unfunded and the connection under SR 520 is unfunded.

mtp-project.title: Meridian Avenue E/SR 161 at 176th Street E Park & Ride (South Hill)
mtp-project.description: 350 new parking stalls
mtp-project.planning-process: Pierce County – Title 19A – Comprehensive Plan (Adopted 1994; Transit Element not Updated in 2013 along with the rest of the Plan) • Objective 1. TRANSIT: Recognize that transit and ridesharing are important elements of the transportation system. • H. Transit Access: Pierce County encourages transit access by: 1. Improving bicycle and pedestrian access to proposed transit centers, rail stations, and bus stops. 2. Working with Pierce Transit and the development industry to integrate transit facilities (e.g., transfer centers, bus pullouts, bus shelters, transit information centers) and safe and convenient pedestrian and bicycle connections into residential, retail, manufacturing, commercial, and other types of activity centers.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, not yet as funding for the project has not been secured. Nor has an initial site assessment been conducted, etc.
mtp-project.location: Please delete the Endpoints listed below (i.e., leave blank)
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

mtp-project.title: I-5 at SR 167 Interchange Park & Ride (Fife)
mtp-project.description: 1,000 new parking stalls, as identified in the SR 167 - Puyallup to SR 509 Tier II FEIS (pp. 3-363 to 3-364)
mtp-project.planning-process: The project is specifically identified in the WSDOT SR 167: Puyallup to SR 509 (SR 167 Puyallup River Bridge Replacement) Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement on pages 3-363 to 3-364.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Although the project is currently unprogrammed, it assumed that WSDOT concurrence was reached as part of the SR 167 Tier II FEIS process.
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

cosponsor.name: WSDOT Olympic Region in Pierce Countywide Area

mtp-project.title: 6th Avenue/Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 Transit Corridor Service
mtp-project.description: Additional core service in the 6th Avenue/Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 corridors to 15-minute frequencies plus vehicle needs (4 additional coaches)
mtp-project.planning-process: The 2015 Tacoma Transportation Master Plan currently in development cites in Chapter 4 "Future Vision," Section 3.13, "Encourage transit ridership by implementing pedestrian improvements near transit stops, conducting outreach to employers, and working with public transit agencies to identify strategies to improve the frequency and ridership of transit service, including bus, streetcar, and light rail, between high density residential areas and employment centers. These strategies would include locating transit stops/stations to maximize convenience of transfers between modes and/or connecting to other routes." In addition, Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 is labeled a "high" Transit Network Intensity Corridor on the accompanying Transit Priority Corridors map.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, concurrence is not required since the project would increase transit service in an already existing transit corridor (Route 1).
mtp-project.funds-description: While the Route 1 is already funded in Pierce Transit's operating budget, no funds have been identified for a future service expansion or additional vehicles to date.

mtp-project.title: I-5:Thorne Lane to Gravelly Lake Dr.-Frontage Road
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes the project is in the metropolitan transportation plan.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes
mtp-project.funds-description: $6 million of state motor vehicle account funds have been committed to this corridor for IJRs and NEPA evaluation. Construction funds would need to come from a new transportation revenue package.

mtp-project.title: I-5/JBLM Thorne Lane Interchange
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes it is in the metropolitan transportation plan.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes.
mtp-project.funds-description: There are $6 million of state motor vehicle funds committed to the IJRs and NEPA evaluation for this corridor.

mtp-project.title: I-5/JBLM Berkeley Drive I/C
mtp-project.planning-process: Included in the metropolitan transportation plan.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes
mtp-project.funds-description: $6 million in state motor vehicle funds are committed to doing IJRs and a NEPA evaluation for the corridor. This work is on-going.

mtp-project.title: I-5/JBLM DuPont-Steilacoom-New Interchange
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes
mtp-project.funds-description: There are $6 million committed to completing the IJR and NEPA evaluation for the corridor. Construction funding will be associated with the passage of a new revenue for transportation package. $20 million of the estimate is for constructing a relocated security gate for JBLM.

mtp-project.title: 112th Streets E/S (Route 4) Transit Corridor Service
mtp-project.description: Additional core service in the 112th Street E/S corridors to 15-minute frequencies plus vehicle needs (5 additional coaches).
mtp-project.planning-process: City of Lakewood - Comprehensive Plan – Chapter 6 – Transportation (Adopted 2000) 6.7 Reassessment Strategy - Aggressively pursue the following TDM strategies, including management actions in dense commercial centers: o Partner with Pierce Transit to identify public and/or private funding for expanded transit service during peak and off-peak times along LOS-deficient corridors. City of Puyallup - Transportation Element of Comprehensive Plan (Amended 2010) o Expanding services in southern and eastern Pierce County, providing more frequent service on S. Meridian Avenue East (WA 161) and expanding service offerings in the South Hill area ; o Providing local and express service within Pierce County for commuters and non-commuters to allow them to travel in a faster and more efficient manner without depending on an automobile; o Additional revenue is needed to pay for more service. • Local Express Services – Center Connections: Frequent bus service between (the) South Hill area and downtown Puyallup are currently provided by Pierce Transit. In the future, the frequency is expected to increase with the increased demand in the transit users in the region.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, concurrence is not necessary as fixed route bus transit service in the corridor already exists.
mtp-project.funds-description: While the new Route 4 is already funded in Pierce Transit's operating budget, no funds have been identified for a future service expansion or additional vehicles to date.

mtp-project.title: I-5 Steilacoom/DuPont I/C to Thorne Lane
mtp-project.description: Construct additional SB and NB lanes
mtp-project.planning-process: This change is to extend the limits of the project to be consistent with the updated scope of work for expanding I-5 through the JBLM vicinity. It is consistent with the candidate project currently in T2040 except for the southern limit.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: This change is consistent with the direction of the I-5 JBLM task force that is represented by local agencies, FHWA, TRPC and PSRC.
mtp-project.location: I-5 Steilacoom/DuPont I/C to Thorne Lane I/C
mtp-project.funds-description: There is $6 million committed by the State Legislature for IJR and NEPA evaluation for the corridor. Construction funds will need to be included in a new transportation revenue package.

mtp-project.title: HCT/Limited Stop Bus Service: Pacific Avenue S/ SR 7
mtp-project.description: Limited Stop Bus Service (HCT) on Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 from Downtown Tacoma to 8th Avenue E in Spanaway (Route 1). This route was identified in the Transit Competitive Index and is considered a Pierce County Congested Corridor.
mtp-project.planning-process: Not specifically, although high capacity transit is mentioned in the 2015 Tacoma Transportation Master Plan, currently in development. In addition, Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 is labeled a "high" Transit Network Intensity Corridor on the accompanying Transit Priority Corridors map.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, but WSDOT concurrence will be requested once a high capacity transit feasibility study is completed by Pierce Transit for both the Pacific Avenue S/SR 7 and S. Meridian/SR 161 corridors.
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

mtp-project.title: HCT/Limited Stop Bus Service: S. Meridian/SR 161
mtp-project.description: Limited Stop Bus Service (HCT) on S. Meridian/SR 161 from 176th Street E to downtown Puyallup
mtp-project.planning-process: "The City is currently planning to design and build a Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system along Meridian corridor between downtown Puyallup and the southern city limits. Puyallup has received a 1.5 million dollar federal funding allocation to complete an Alternatives Analysis (AA) to determine the feasibility of BRT in this area. The BRT would include a special branding of service, e.g., a catchy name like EZRA or Easy Rider Access. This project is identified in the City’s LIFT program, and is intended to provide frequent bus-connections and increased reliability of transit service to/from the city’s downtown with South Hill job development areas. Transit stations/stops with good signage and Intelligent Transportation Systems features including Transit-signal priority would be a part of this project to increase the transit reliability and operations along the corridor. Depending on the availability of grants and funding, the design for the project would be completed by 2010 and the construction would be completed by 2011." Source: City of Puyallup Comprehensive Plan - Transportation Element - 2010 Update, p. VI-38
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, none to date. Pierce Transit would first need to have a feasibility study conducted for higher capacity transit service in the both the S. Meridian/SR 161 and Pacific Avenue/SR 7 corridors before seeking concurrence from WSDOT.
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

mtp-project.title: SR 16 Corridor Park & Ride (Gig Harbor)
mtp-project.description: New Park & Ride lot with 300-600 parking stalls at a location to be determined on the Gig Harbor peninsula.
mtp-project.planning-process: Not specifically. Although supporting language is found in the City of Gig Harbor Comprehensive Plan - Transportation Element update of 2015, as follows: "Supporting effective public transportation services to help reduce car dependence in the region and serve the needs of people who rely on public transportation." (Draft dated 3/19/15, p. 12-64)
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No, not yet, as the exact project location is yet to be determined. Also because the estimated project completion date is not for another 15 years (in 2030).
mtp-project.funds-description: None to date.

mtp-project.title: Mountain to Sound Greenway
mtp-project.description: A paved multiuse trail of 12 feet wide (where feasible) is proposed beginning at the current end of the trail at Factoria Blvd and running eastward along the south side of I-90 and the north side of SE 36th St to the curve near the 150th Ave SE interchange with I-90, then following a new independent alignment to the south of the interchange and north of the 150th Avenue SE/SE 37th St intersection. Eastward from 150th Ave SE, the trail will continue on the south side of I-90 and the north side of SE 37th St. Eastward from the termination of SE 37th St, the trail will continue on the south side of I-90 and the north side of private properties and/or Newport Way to the intersection of Lakemont Blvd SE and Newport Way.
mtp-project.planning-process: City of Bellevue Comprehensive Plan - Pedestrian and Bicycle Transportation Facilities Plan (adopted into the Comprehensive Plan by reference per Ord. 5861, 2/17/09) - project number O-137-N (page 386).
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: In 2011, the Mountains to Sound Greenway Trust and the City of Bellevue worked together with other stakeholders to undertake and prepare a design feasibility analysis of the future trail alignment. The trail study was completed in 2012 with the current revisions.
mtp-project.funds-description: The section of this project between Factoria Blvd and 150th Ave SE has $470,000 in TAP funds for design. Two other sections of the trail received CMAQ grant funds for design in the amount of $500,000 and $296,000 respectively. With the addition of local funds, three sections of the trail are funded for the design phase.

mtp-project.title: Schuster Parkway Promenade
mtp-project.description: Multimodal Trail along Schuster Parkway linking downtown Tacoma with Ruston Way and north end neighborhoods. Design is planned to be complete in 2017 with construction to follow in phases.
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes the project is in the Comprehensive Plan under the transportation element as priority 14 Schuster Parkway Trail. The project is also part of the Capital Improvement Program
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: No affected parties
mtp-project.funds-description: $1,352,800 is constrained for design, $11,890 is estimated for right-of-way (ROW) and $8,890,560 is estimated for construction of the project. Neither ROW or construction for this project are funded.

mtp-project.title: East Lake Sammamish Trail - North
mtp-project.planning-process: yes

mtp-project.title: East Lake Sammamish Trail - Issaquah Segment
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes
mtp-project.funds-description: local funds

mtp-project.title: SR 410 Channelization: Mtn. Villa Dr. to Watson St. N.
mtp-project.description: This project will provide for channelization, roadway, and pedestrian facility improvements along an existing section of the State Route 410 corridor within the City of Enumclaw. The project will modify and optimize the existing 65-foot wide, variable (2-to-4) lane channelization to a proposed 5-lane configuration; one-through lane and one general purpose (through/right turning) lane for each direction with medians, continuous two-way left turn lanes, or left turn pockets as approved by WSDOT. The project will add or upgrade curb, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, storm drainage, illumination, and curb ramps along the SR 410 corridor between mileposts 24.34 to 24.81.
mtp-project.planning-process: Enumclaw Comprehensive Plan "Winds of Change", Chapter 5, Page 22, ID # R4a & b.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: WSDOT has approved Channelization Plan (revised) in Feb. 2015 -and- to date Agency is currently awaiting issuance of a WSDOT General Permit for finalization of PS&E Bid Package and then to proceed with FHWA CN Obligation for Ad & Award.
mtp-project.funds-description: Local funds to complete PE Phase and the CN match amount were committed by adoption of the 2015 city budget in Dec. 2014. $1,495,545 CN Federal funds were awarded by PSRC in Nov. 2014. Obligation approval by WSDOT expected in April 2015

mtp-project.title: Core or Swift BRT - SR 527 Downtown Bothell to SR 526/I-5
mtp-project.description: Swift II Bus Rapid Transit will be Community Transit's 2nd line of BRT, traveling between the Canyon Park Park & Ride and Paine Field/Boeing. This 12 mile corridor will have 15 stations in each direction served by 60 ft articulated buses. Swift II BRT will meet a critical need for east-west transportation options in Snohomish County, connecting a Regional Growth Center (Canyon Park) with a Regional Manufacturing and Industrial Growth Center (Paine Field). This service will be all day bi-directional service operating at a 10 min frequency during peak hours.
mtp-project.planning-process: This project is identified in Community Transit's 20 year Long Range Transit Plan and our 2015-2019 Transit Development Plan as one of Community Transit's "Transit Emphasis Corridors" a network that represents the future investment of high capacity transit service
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Community Transit is currently in the middle of Project Development for Swift II BRT in order to qualify for federal FTA Small Starts funding. Affected parties include City of Everett, WSDOT, Snohomish County, City of Mill Creek and the City of Bothell. Joint work is being done with all affected jurisdictions.
mtp-project.funds-description: Community Transit currently has $4.2 million dollars to complete project development for Swift II BRT. We are also on the list of proposed projects for the Washington State Regional Mobility grant program for $8.5 million dollars for the Seaway Transit Center the northern terminus of Swift II BRT. We will submit for a rating to the FTA Small Starts grant program in Fall 2015 with the intent to sign a SSGA in Fall of 2016.

secondary-improvement-type.name: New Or Expanded Transit Center or Station

mtp-project.title: Historic Water Ditch Trail Phase IV
mtp-project.description: Phase IV -- construct an active transportation shared use path adjacent to South Tacoma Way from South M Street to South C Street.
mtp-project.planning-process: This project is listed in the Transportation Element of the Comprehensive Plan under section T-ICCP-2 Active Transportation Regional Coordination as well as Priority #13 on the short term bicycle project priority list.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: N/A
mtp-project.funds-description: There is CMAQ and City matching funds for both design and construction of this phase of the project.

mtp-project.title: Bel-Red Regional Connectivity - NE Spring Boulevard (Phase 1)
mtp-project.description: The project will design a new east-west roadway between 116th Avenue NE and 124th Avenue NE. The cross section of NE Spring Boulevard from 116th Avenue NE to 120th Avenue NE will include two travel lanes in each direction with a separated wide multi-use path on the north side and sidewalk on the south side. The cross section between 120th and 124th Avenues NE will include two travel lanes in each direction with widened outside lanes for shared bicycle use and wide sidewalks on both sides. Both sections will include signalized intersections connected to the city's traffic adaptive control system, turn pockets, center turn lanes where appropriate, landscaping, lighting, and storm water treatment and drainage facilities. NE Spring Blvd will be designed in coordination with Sound Transit's East Link light rail project, including a planned overcrossing of the rail alignment and a planned station in the vicinity of 120th Avenue NE.
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes, the City of Bellevue Comprehensive Plan - Bel-Red Subarea Plan - Project #107, page 48. The separated path associated w/NE 15th (Spring Blvd) is referenced within the Pedestrian and Bicycle Transportation Facilities Plan as depicted on the map on page 57. The NE 15th St(Spring Blvd) project directly supports the primary goal of Bellevue's Transportation & Land Use policies: To implement a fully multi-modal transportation system that supports the land use vision of the Comprehensive Plan and the role of Downtown Bellevue as the Eastside Urban Center(page 121 of the Comprehensive Plan within the Transportation Element).
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Yes, Resolution 8718, approved 3/17/14 officially changed the name of NE 15th St to Spring Blvd. The name evokes the renewal of the Bel-Red Regional District and references the Spring District development that will anchor the west edge of Bel-Red.
mtp-project.funds-description: The original budget for the design of this project is $6,453,000 of which $3,000,000 in STP funds will be obligated in the next month to take the design from 60% to 100%. There is $3,453,000 in local fund of which $1,610,000 in local funds has already been spent to get the project to 60% design.

mtp-project.title: Historic Water Ditch Trail Phase III
mtp-project.description: Phase III --construct an active transportation shared use path adjacent to South Tacoma Way between S. Pine Street and S. M Street.
mtp-project.planning-process: Yes, it is listed in T-ICCP-2 Active Transportation Regional Coordination and is priority 13 on the short term bicycle project priority list on Table 2 in the Transportation Element.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: N/A
mtp-project.funds-description: There is $700,000 in funds for phase III & IV in a joint grant. It is approximated $375,000 will be used for design of phase III and the remainder spent on phase IV. There is an unfunded construction need of approx. $6,500,000 and the City will be applying for grant funds for this project as grant opportunities are presented.

mtp-project.title: State Ave. 116th St. NE to 136th St. NE
mtp-project.description: Widening the segment of State Avenue between 116th Street NE and 136th Street NE from three lanes to five. Other elements include installation of sidewalk on the east side of the road, improvements to the “Arlington Spur” railroad crossing, and upgrade of the traffic signal at 128th Street NE.
mtp-project.planning-process: Project is identified in the City of Marysville Transportation Comprehensive Plan as well as in the 6 year TIP
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Project is fully within the City of Marysville
mtp-project.funds-description: $3,000,000 in TIB funding $1,279,440 in Local funding

mtp-project.title: SR 526 Corridor Safety & Capacity Improvements
mtp-project.description: Construct improvements to SR 526 to improve safety and provide congestion relief such as peak shoulder use and intersection improvements.
mtp-project.planning-process: This project is included in WSDOT's capital improvement program.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: This project will be done in coordination with the City of Everett.
mtp-project.funds-description: Project funding is all new revenue, as currently proposed by the state legislature. The new revenue proposal was passed by the Senate in the current legislative session.

mtp-project.title: SR 9 @ SR 204 Intersection Improvement
mtp-project.planning-process: The project is included in WSDOT's approved capital improvement program and was developed under a pre-design study done by WSDOT in September 2012.
mtp-project.letters-of-concurrence: Concurrence was given by the City of Lake Stevens.
mtp-project.funds-description: $500,000, funded by Federal STP and state funds, was previously authorized for a traffic study; $229,406 was actually expended.
